awd_titl_txt: Phase Transition Phenomena in Random Graphs
awd_abstract_narration:
Mathematically well-understood random graphs serve as reference models which can guide the analysis and design of (models for) real world networks such as communication networks, social networks, or food chains. This project aims at developing and advancing mathematical tools and techniques for analyzing various random graphs, including "dynamic" models (i.e., graphs that grow step-by-step in a random way). The dynamic aspect is conceptually important since (a) many real-world networks also grow over time, whereas (b) the majority of the existing mathematical random graphs literature focuses on "static" models. This project thus contributes to the interdisciplinary effort of understanding networks, which are nowadays omnipresent in real life as well as in data science, complex networks, and many other disciplines. 

This project explores a topic which is central to the theory of random graphs: the phase transition phenomenon in the component structure (from only "small" components to a "giant" component dominating most of the graph). The PI will investigate this fundamental and striking phenomenon in several difficult-to-analyze random graph models, with particular emphasis on (the finite-size scaling behavior of) the size of the largest component in models with non-trivial dependencies between the edges. Two principle aims are (i) to advance our general understanding of the phase transition, and (ii) to improve the mathematical proof techniques in the area, in particular to make them more robust (so that they apply to a wider range of models).
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This project was in the area of probabilistic combinatorics, in particular the study of random graphs/networks and related random discrete structures. One goal was to better understand the phase transition phenomenon, which intuitively refers to the sudden change of the graph structure (from only small components to one "giant" component which dominates the whole graph). Another goal was to use these random structures to solve problems in other areas of research, in particular combinatorics. 

Intellectual Merit. A major focus of this project was on modern random graphs, in particular on those that evolve over time (by adding edges step-by-step). Here we proved several phase transition results, including a conjecture of Pittel regarding the phase transition of a preferential attachment random graph process. Furthermore, we obtained several applications of evolving random graphs in extremal and probabilistic combinatorics. Notably, we proved the approximate version of an old Erdos conjecture (from 1973) on locally sparse Steiner triple systems, by developing and analyzing a suitably constrained random graph process. Furthermore, we proved a Ramsey-Theory conjecture of Fox-Grinshpun-Liebenau-Person-Szabo, by developing and analyzing a robust variant of the so-called triangle-free process. In this context we, for example, also gave a shorter and simpler proof of a key proof-technique in the area (Wormald's differential equation method). The technical advancements we developed for obtaining these results will help the analysis of other evolving random processes, and several new applications of our ideas have indeed already emerged.

Broader Impacts. As a key part of the broader impacts we mentored and trained junior researchers, including two graduate students, three undergraduate students, and one postdoctoral researcher (actively involving them in the project). Another aspect of the broader impact involved outreach activities to K12 mathematics teachers: besides facilitating training sessions, we also organized a new day-long workshop in collaboration with the Atlanta Math Teacher's circle. In addition, we broadly disseminated our research through talks at numerous institutions, and organized several special sessions at conferences.


Last Modified: 09/01/2023
Modified by: Lutz Warnke
